Research article Revealing the mechanism of selective hydrogenation of oleic acid on bifunctional hierarchical catalysts Zhentao Liu Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Jinlin Mei Supervision Software Formal analysis Xiaoyang Kong Resources Investigation Dongze Li Software Yutong Zou Investigation Chunya Wang Methodology Funding acquisition Yanjun Gong Visualization Validation Aijun Duan Funding acquisition Formal analysis Chunming Xu Resources Methodology Xilong Wang Writing – review & editing Visualization Validation Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (Beijing), Beijing 102249, PR China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum (Beijing) Beijing 102249 PR China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (Beijing), Beijing 102249, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Bifunctional hierarchical porous Ni/ZSM-22-KIT-6 (Ni/ZK) catalysts with uniform mesostructure and tunable acidity were synthesized and applied to the selective hydrogenation of oleic acid for jet fuel production. The open hierarchical porous channels of Ni/ZK not could facilitate the dispersion of Ni species and reduce the diffusion resistance, but also provide a large number of adsorption sites for reactants. The acidity of the Ni/ZK catalyst was optimized by adjusting the addition of ZSM-22 seeds, and the acidic supports would affect the metal-support interaction and the electronic properties of Ni species. Moreover, the reaction mechanism and pathway were investigated by in situ FT-IR spectrometer, demonstrating that the acid strength could affect the deoxygenation pathway and isomerization/hydrocracking pathway. Overall, Ni/ZK-2 possessed higher jet fuel yield of 60.2 % and iso/n-alkane ratio of 5.6 at 320 °C compared with other heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literatures. For comparison, the iso/n-alkane ratio of commercial Jet A-1 is 1.11, indicating that the jet fuel derived from oleic acid hydrogenation over Ni/ZK-2 possessed enhanced resistance to condensation. Keywords Micro-mesoporous catalyst Open hierarchical porous channel Acidity Oleic acid Selective hydrogenation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The unsustainability of fossil fuels as a non-renewable source of energy and the generated carbon emissions were highly concerned by many countries under the dual-carbon background [1–3]. Moreover, the International Energy Agency (IEA) had set the CO2 emissions from the aviation sector at zero by 2050. To achieve energy conservation and emission reduction targets, the adoption of bio-jet fuel currently stands as the most viable solution [4,5]. Among bio-jet fuel production pathways, waste oil hydrogenation demonstrated exceptional potential and the jet fuel derived from this process exhibited superior physicochemical properties. The hydrogenation of waste oil to jet fuel included hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), hydroisomerization (ISO) and hydrocracking (HCK). Moreover, iso-alkanes were regarded as one of the ideal components of jet fuel because the presence of iso-alkanes could effectively lower the condensation point and enhance the flow properties of jet fuel [6–8]. However, the imbalance between HCK activity and ISO activity always led to the inability to obtain both highly selective iso-alkanes and high yield of jet fuel in the hydrogenation process. Addressing this issue remained a primary research focus, with the development of highly active and selective hydrogenation catalysts emerging as a pivotal strategy. Zeolites with large specific surface area, superior acidic properties and unique pore structures had been extensively employed in catalytic reactions [9–11]. Among various zeolites, ZSM-22 with ten-member ring channels of 0.45 × 0.54 nm had been widely used in ISO reactions owing to its unique “key-lock” mechanism and mild acid property [12–14]. However, the application of ZSM-22 in waste oil hydrogenation processes was constrained by the high diffusion resistance encountered by macromolecules. In contrast, ordered mesoporous materials such as KIT-6 had recently garnered research interest owing to its enhanced diffusion efficiency [15,16]. Although mesoporous materials possessed good diffusion efficiency for reactants, their reactivity of ISO and HCK decreased greatly under the limitation of the poor acidity. Micro-mesoporous composites could combine the advantages of both the acidic property of ZSM-22 and the high diffusion efficiency of KIT-6. Furthermore, the reaction pathway and the selective activation of CC and CO bonds were critically influenced by catalyst acidity. Catalysts with weak acid preferred decarboxylation (DCX) or decarbonylation (DCN) paths, on the contrary, catalysts with strong acid were more prone to the reductive deoxygenation (RDO) path [17,18]. Therefore, it is necessary to optimize the acidity of the catalyst to increase the yield of jet fuel in the reaction process. Ni supported catalysts had been extensively utilized in various catalytic hydrogenation reactions owing to their good catalytic activity and cost-effectiveness. However, higher metal loadings usually led to the poor metal dispersion and problem of metal aggregation. Recently Cho et al. reported that one-step melt infiltration (OSMI) method was an excellent loading method to obtain high dispersion of Ni metal particles by optimizing the pretreatment conditions and heating procedures [19,20]. The catalysts loaded by OSMI method exhibited a better dispersion of active metals compared with initial wetness impregnation, turn to facilitate the catalytic performance. In this work, micro-mesoporous Ni/ZK catalysts with both acidity properties of ZSM-22 and superior diffusion performance of KIT-6 were successfully synthesized. The effects of acidity and hierarchical porous structure of Ni/ZK catalysts on the activity and selectivity of selective hydrogenation of oleic acid were studied systematically. Besides, a possible reaction mechanism of selective hydrogenation of oleic acid was proposed according to the results of in situ FT-IR spectrometer and the products distribution. The optimized Ni/ZK-2 catalyst possessed excellent performance with higher jet fuel yield of 60.2 % and the ratio of iso-alkanes to n-alkanes (iso/n) of 5.6 compared with other heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literatures. This work provided a new insight for the highly selective production of jet fuel with high iso-alkanes content. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Supports and catalysts preparation The details of preparation of supports and catalysts methods were provided in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Characterization of the supports and the catalysts In order to investigate the physical and chemical properties of the series of catalysts, different characterization methods, such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer, in situ FT-IR spectrometer, X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS), transmission electron microscope (TEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) were used in order to describe the correlation between the catalyst properties and the catalytic reaction activity. The details of characterization methods were provided in the Supporting Information. 2.3 Catalytic activity test 5 wt% of oleic was dissolved in cyclohexane solution as the feedstock, and the catalytic performance was carried out on the fixed-bed reactor. 1 g catalysts were sieved into 40–60 meshes and loaded in the middle section in the reaction tube. Meanwhile, the sides of the catalysts were fixed by quartz cottons and quartz sands. All catalysts were reduced at a H2 flow rate of 100 mL min−1 and 460 °C for 4 h, the evaluation of reaction performance was carried out at the temperature of 300–380 °C, the reaction pressure of 4 MPa, H2/oil ratio of 400 and weight hour space velocities (WHSVs) of 10 h−1. The liquid products (LPs) were collected and analyzed by Agilent 7890B gas chromatography/5977A mass spectrometry (GC/MS) instrument. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthetic mechanism of ZK-x composites Micro-mesoporous composites were synthesized by self-assembly method and the reasonable synthetic mechanism for ZK-x were depicted in scheme 1 . P123 and TEOS were chosen as the templating agent and silicon source, respectively. n-butanol was chosen as a cosolute to form co-micelles with the block copolymers, stabilizing the polar-polar interface in order to optimize the micellar interfacial curvature [21]. Firstly, the effective hydrophilic group of n-butanol interacted with P123 and the OH group mainly located at the hydrophilic-hydrophobic interface of the micelles. With the addition of TEOS, the negatively charged TEOS and the structure-directing agent self-assembled into silicified micelles, and the spherical micelles converted to linear micelles. Then ZSM-22 seeds were introduced into the gel system, and the silicified micelles and ZSM-22 basic structure units further self-assembled into the composite micelles. Over time, n-butanol migrated to a more hydrophilic environment, leading to a further decrease in the curvature of the micelles, resulting in the generation of the Ia3̅d cubic phase. Ultimately, ordered micro-mesoporous ZK-x composites with ZSM-22 crystal structures were formed. 3.2 Characterization of the supports and catalysts As depicted in Fig. 1 a, b, all the micro-mesoporous materials possessed the characteristic diffraction peaks at around 8.1°, 20.3°, 24.1° and 25.6° attributed to the TON topology according to the standard patterner of ZSM-22 (JCPDS card No. 78-1419) [22], indicating that all the composite materials had the ZSM-22 basic structure units. In addition, the intensity of TON topology characteristic diffraction peaks of the ZK composites increased with higher ZSM-22 seeds content [23]. Composite materials displayed the characteristic diffraction peaks at around 0.88°, 1° and 1.5°–1.6°, corresponding to the (211), (220), (321), (400), (420) and (332) planes of KIT-6, and the characteristic peaks intensity decreased as the ZSM-22 units increased, due to the decrease in the orderness of the pore structure (Fig. 1c). The existence of the XRD characteristic peaks proved that the micro-mesoporous composites both possessed the well-ordered mesopores and ZSM-22 basic structure unit [24,25]. The similar trend was observed in the IR spectrum (Fig. 1d). The intensities of the stretching peaks assigned to the lattice vibrations of ZSM-22 at 552 cm−1, 560 cm−1, 784 cm−1 and 810 cm−1 exhibited a decreasing trend as the ZSM-22 seed content reduced. [26]. All composites exhibited the similar crystal structure, suggesting that ZSM-22 seeds were well combined with KIT-6. As shown in Fig. 1e, f, compared with ZSM-22, composites exhibited a Ⅳ typical isotherm and typical H4 hysteresis loop at the relative pressure range of 0.4–0.9 due to the capillary condensation, which was consistent with the characteristic curve of KIT-6. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of supports series were listed in Table S1. The mesopore size of all the composites was concentrated around 10–20 nm, with the mesopore amount decreasing as the ZSM-22 seed content increased. The existence of mesopores in composites could effectively reduce the diffusion resistance. In addition, the large specific surface area would improve the accessibility of the reactants to the active metal and facilitate the dispersion of the active metal. Fig. 1b showed three characteristic diffraction peaks at around 2θ = 37.3°, 43.3° and 62.9°, attributed to the structure of NiO (JCPDS card No. 78-0423). Compared with Ni/ZSM-22, all composites displayed the broader full width at half maximum (FWHM) of NiO diffraction peaks, and the diffraction peaks gradually became gentle. Therefore, the lower and weaker diffraction peak of Ni/ZK-x demonstrated that composites possessed a better dispersion of NiO species [27,28]. The morphology of ZK-x supports and Ni/ZK-x catalysts was characterized via SEM and TEM analyses. SEM images of various supports were depicted in Fig. S1, ZSM-22 exhibited a short stick morphology with a size of 200 nm, and the overall appearance of KIT-6 was amorphous. Notably, micro-mesoporous composites retained an amorphous appearance, and the EDS mapping of ZK-x exhibited a coexistence and uniform distribution of Si, O and Al elements, which proved that ZSM-22 were well embedded into the KIT-6 mesoporous materials. As shown in Fig. S2, all ZK-x supports except ZK-1 exhibited a well-defined Ia3̅d mesoporous structure, characterized by the highly ordered pore channels. As depicted in Fig. 2 a, ZK-2 exhibited an amorphous appearance similar to KIT-6, and possessed an orderly and regular pore structure (Fig. 2b). Besides, Ni/ZK-2 exhibited a good dispersion of Ni species and the size of Ni species was concentrated around 15 nm (Fig. 2c), significantly smaller than those supported on ZSM-22, which highlighted the role of mesopores in enhancing metal dispersion. As shown in Fig. 2(d), the EDS mapping images of Ni/ZK-2 exhibited the coexistence and uniform dispersion of Si, Al, Ni and O elements, indicating the formation of composites and the well dispersion of Ni. Moreover, the HRTEM of Ni/ZK-2 identified the lattice spacing of Ni was 0.204 nm and 0.206 nm (Fig. 2e), which corresponded to the Ni (111) plane [29]. As depicted in Fig. S3, Ni species had been successfully supported on supports series, and Ni/ZK-x exhibited a higher dispersion of Ni and a smaller Ni particle size compared with Ni/ZSM-22. Moreover, the average Ni particle size decreased with the decrease of the ZSM-22 seeds content, which proved that mesopore played a pivotal role in promoting the Ni species dispersion [30–33]. To further validate the superior diffusion performance of hierarchical porous materials, the diffusion and adsorption properties of TMB (1,3,5-triethylbenzene) on catalysts series at 25 °C were systematically investigated via IGA (Intelligent Gravimetric Analyze). As depicted in Fig. 3 a, TMB was absorbed rapidly because of the capillary condensation effect when P/P0 = 0.4–0.8. Notably, Ni/ZK-x catalysts exhibited significantly higher TMB adsorption capacities than Ni/ZSM-22, with the adsorption capacity increasing proportionally with mesopore volume. This trend confirmed that hierarchical porous structures provide abundant adsorption sites for reactants. Besides, Fig. 3b showed that the D/L2 values increased in the order of Ni/ZSM-22 (6.1 × 10−3 s−1) < Ni/ZK-1 (1.3 × 10−3 s−1) < Ni/ZK-2 (0.8 × 10−3 s−1). The results clearly supported that the presence of mesopores in the hierarchical porous catalysts facilitated the diffusion of TMB, and the enhancement was consistent with the trend in the mesopores volume of catalysts [6,34]. Overall, the introduction of mesopores not only enhanced the adsorption capacity for reactants, but also minimized the diffusion resistance, thereby accelerating the rapid conversion of reactants and intermediates and ultimately improving improved reactivity. The incorporation of ZSM-22 zeolite seeds significantly influenced catalyst acidity, as extensively documented in prior literatures [10,23,24,35,36]. In order to further investigate the relationship between acid type and acid strength on the catalytic reaction activity, Py-IR, NH3-TPD were adopted to characterize and study the intrinsic connection between acid properties and catalytic reactions. As depicted in Fig. 4 a, b, the spectra with pyridine adsorption at degassing temperatures of 200 °C and 350 °C correspond to the total acidity and medium-strength acidity of the catalyst series, respectively. The acid type and amount were listed in the Table 1 . It was widely accepted that the activation of CO bonds and CO of reactants and intermediates were closely related to the Brønsted (B) acid center. However, the presence of Lewis (L) acids and strong B acid sites would result in series of excessive cracking side reactions, leading to a greatly decrease of LPs yield [27]. IR spectra in the hydroxyl vibration region of catalysts was depicted in Fig. 4c, the intensity of the peaks attributed to the external isolated silanol species at 3740 cm−1 and the bridging hydroxyl acid site species at 3600 cm−1 decreased as the addition of ZSM-22 seeds decreased, and the change trend in the amount of acid was consistent with the results of Py-IR. Notably, the vibrational peaks attributed to the extra-framework aluminum species did not appear at 3660 cm−1, suggesting that the ZSM-22 structural unit was well integrated with the KIT-6 [37]. NH3-TPD profiles (Fig. 4d) further corroborated the direct proportionality between ZSM-22 seed content and the acid amount results listed in the Table 1 [38]. The redox performance of Ni species was characterized by H2-TPR (Fig. 4e). Ni/ZK-x exhibited the higher reduction temperature and higher consumption area of H2 than Ni/ZSM-22 and Ni/KIT-6. This enhancement was attributed to optimized metal-support interaction (MSI) and Ni dispersion under the synergistic effect of acidity and mesopores [39]. As depicted in Fig. 4g, the Ni, O, Si and Al elements could be identified for all the catalysts, and the chemical composition state of Ni was shown in Fig. 4f. Critically, Ni/ZK-x exhibited a higher proportion of Ni⁰ species (Table S2), owing to improved Ni dispersion would expose more reducible active sites. Besides, the binding energy of Ni0 species on Ni/ZK-x tended to shift toward the high binding energy compare with Ni/KIT-6, indicating that the occurrence of electron transfer between B acid sites and Ni species [40], which was commonly associated with the formation of Ni species with “electron-deficient” effect [41]. With the decrease of ZSM-22 seeds, the shift in binding energy of Ni0 species became weaker, consistent with the decrease of acid amount and the weaken of the electron transfer effect. Under the limitation of high saturation vapor pressure of oleic acid, valeric acid (VA) was chosen as a probe molecule to investigate the adsorption and reaction mechanism on series of catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 5 a–c, the characteristic peaks of VA were observed in the adsorption process in supports series, exhibiting time dependent intensity enhancement. The adsorption peaks at 3740 cm−1 were significantly reduced and even negative (Fig. 5g), implying the decrease and depletion of surface SiOH groups via VA adsorption [42,43]. The apparent peaks at 1618 cm−1 were attributed to the bidentate bridging adsorption of carboxylic acid, and the strong adsorption peaks at 1710 cm−1 were attribute to the physical adsorption of carboxylic acid [44]. The hydrogenation reaction intermediates at 320 °C were investigated in Fig. 5d–f. The carboxyl groups in gaseous VA were rapidly converted to the pre-reaction phase. As time progresses, the characteristic peaks at 1737 cm−1 attributed to esters bonds were clearly observed in Ni/ZK-2 and Ni/KIT-6 because of the high amount of silica hydroxyls, which was consistent with the results of IR spectra in the hydroxyl vibration region. The adsorption model in the silica hydroxyl groups was proposed in Fig. 5j (i). However, after the reaction at 320 °C, the peak at 1737 cm−1 was almost disappeared for Ni/ZK-2 compare with Ni/KIT-6. Besides, pair of bands at 1650 cm−1 and 1382 cm−1 (Δν = 268 cm−1) and 1573 cm−1 and 1465 cm−1 (Δν = 108 cm−1) were observed in the reaction of Ni/ZSM-22 and Ni/ZK-2, which were corresponded to monodentate carboxyl species on the L acid sites and chelating bidentate carboxyl species on the B acid site, respectively [45]. The adsorption models in the L and B acid sites were proposed in Fig. 5j (ii, iii) [46]. Compared with Ni/ZK-2, Ni/ZSM-22 possessed the stronger peak at 1573 cm−1, indicating that VA adsorbed on the acidic site was not fully converted. H2-TPR revealed that stronger MSI would promote the dispersion of Ni species. Ni/ZK-2 demonstrated superior hydrogenation efficiency over Ni/ZSM-22 due to the smaller Ni particles exposed more active sites and open mesopores enabled unimpeded reactants diffusion to active centers, as evidenced by IGA characterization. While Ni/KIT-6 similarly possessed open mesopores and small particle size of Ni species, its deficient acidity (Fig. S4) impaired critical CO/CO bond cleavage. Conversely, strong acid sites caused the robust adsorption of carboxyl groups and led to reactants accumulation that inhibited subsequent hydrogenation steps in Ni/ZSM-22 catalytic system. These comparative observations led us to speculate that the suitable acid property was crucial for effective carboxyl group hydrogenation. Notably, all catalysts exhibited CH4 adsorption peaks at 3016 cm−1 (Fig. 5d–f) and CO adsorption peaks at 2107 cm−1 (Fig. 5h). [47] No CO2 or H2O characteristic peaks were observed, as CO2 converted to CO and CH4 under H2 atmosphere, and water desorbed at high temperatures during in situ FT-IR spectrometer investigation. As depicted in Fig. 5i, Ni/ZSM-22 and Ni/ZK-2 exhibited a distinct adsorption peak of chelating bidentate and monodentate carboxyl species compared with Ni/KIT-6, which was because KIT-6 possessed very few acidic sites. Besides, Ni/ZK-2 and Ni/KIT-6 exhibited a stronger adsorption peak of esters bonds at 1737 cm−1 because of the large amount of SiOH groups. Fig. 5i demonstrated that VA was adsorbed on the L-, B-acid sites and SiOH on Ni/ZK-2, and the adsorbed VA was completely converted after the hydrogenation reaction, indicating the superior properties of micro-mesoporous catalysts. Overall, Ni/ZK-2 exhibited efficient hydrogenation performance because of its high Ni dispersion, high diffusion performance, suitable MSI and acidity. 3.3 Activity test of oleic acid hydrogenation The performance of oleic acid hydrogenation to jet fuel over catalysts at different temperature were investigated. As depicted in Fig. 6 a–f, all catalysts exhibited 100 % deoxygenation rate, evidenced by the disappearance of carboxylate group characteristic peak at 1710 cm−1 (Fig. 6g). Compared with Ni/ZK-x, Ni/ZSM-22 possessed lower yield of LPs due to the strong acid. Besides, the yield of jet fuel (C9–C16) was lower than Ni/ZK-2, which was due to fewer reactive active sites exposed by Ni species with poor dispersion. Moreover, the large mass transfer and diffusion resistance of micropores limited the rapid conversion of reactants and intermediates, leading to the blockage of reactants in the microporous orifices and the intensification of the cracking reaction, which was corroborated by elevated yields of gaseous byproducts and C5–C8 hydrocarbons on Ni/ZSM-22. In contrast, Ni/KIT-6, despite its high Ni dispersion, suffered from insufficient acidity and weak electron-deficiency effects, impeding efficient C17–C18 alkane formation and aromatic hydrocarbon synthesis. Notably, while Ni/KIT-6 achieved full deoxygenation, its weak acidity failed to mediate CC cleavage within the jet fuel range (C9–C16), as reflected in its suboptimal product distribution. Ni/ZK-x combined the advantages of both Ni/KIT-6 and Ni/ZSM-22, not only reduced the mass transfer resistance of the reactants by virtue of a larger pore size, but also optimized the acidity and MSI via changing the amounts of ZSM-22 seeds addition. The yield of LPs and C17-C18 increased with the decrease of ZSM-22 addition, but the yield of jet fuel decreased because the low acidity could inhibit the cleavage of C17-C18. Larger amounts of cracked by-products were generated led to a lower yield of jet fuel and LPs of Ni/ZK-1 compared with other catalysts. Therefore, the activity of the cracking reaction increased with the increase of the acid amount, which was consistent with the tendency in the intensity of the characteristic peaks in Fig. 6g. The large amount of short-chain alkanes generated by the strong HCK reaction would expose more terminal methyl groups, leading to an increase in the characteristic peak intensity attributed to the methyl groups at 1463 cm−1 and 1380 cm−1. The opposite trend was observed at 1473 cm−1 attributed to the methylene group. ZK-2 possessed a highest yield of jet fuel of 60.2 % at 320 °C. The yield of jet fuel on ZK-2 increased and then decreased as the temperature increased, which was because that HCK was a reversible and strong endothermic reaction. Notably, aromatic hydrocarbons were found in the hydrogenation products of Ni/ZK-2, which were the important components of jet fuel. The carbon number distributions of the hydrogenation products on different catalysts were analyzed to unravel reaction mechanisms (Fig. S5). Ni/ZK-3, Ni/ZK-4 and Ni/KIT-6 possessed a higher C17-C18 proportion in the product distribution because their weaker acidity inhibited the HCK activity. Higher C17 than C18 content indicated dominance of DCN/DCX pathways, with C17 yields inversely correlated to acidity confirmed that mild acidic property favored DCN/DCX. After deoxygenation of oleic acid to form long-chain alkanes, the long-chain alkanes underwent a series of HCK and ISO reactions under the synergistic effect of Ni species and acidic sites. Ni/ZSM-22 and Ni/ZK-1 exhibited more C8-C12 hydrocarbons because of their strong HCK activity. Among all the catalysts, Ni/ZK-2 possessed a uniform distribution of alkane with different carbon number (C9–C16), which was because the appropriate acidity and efficient mass transfer properties modulated the balance between the HCK and HDO activities. The presence of iso-paraffins was effective in lowering the condensation point and improving the low-temperature fluidity of jet fuel. Iso/n ratios over different catalysts were depicted in Fig. S6. ISO reactions, thermodynamically exothermic and reversible, were favored at moderate temperatures and mild acid sites. Thus, it was necessary to optimize the acid properties of the catalyst by adjusting the addition of ZSM-22 seeds. Overall, Ni/ZK-2 possessed a superior hydrogenation performance of jet fuel yield (60.2 %) and iso/n ratio (5.6), which was because of the synergistic effect of high dispersion and electron-deficiency effect of Ni, low diffusion resistance, suitable MSI and acidity. To further validate the outstanding catalytic performance of Ni/ZK-2, carboxylic acid with similar carbon number of oleic acid was selected as the reactant and its catalytic performance were listed in Fig. 6h and Table S3. Among the dazzling catalysts, Ni/ZK-2 exhibited both higher yield of jet fuel and iso/n ratio at the similar reaction temperature. The micro-mesoporous catalysts provided a new insight into the hydrogenation of waste oils to the production of jet fuel. The in situ FT-IR spectrometer elucidated the adsorption sites and configurations of carboxyl groups on the catalysts, and the formation of esters observed in the reaction spectra revealed the conversion process of carboxyl groups. These findings provide compelling evidence for the proposed reaction mechanism. Therefore, based on the findings of IR spectra recorded by in situ FT-IR spectrometer and experimental results, a possible reaction pathway for oleic acid hydrogenation was proposed (Fig. 7 ). Firstly, oleic acid adsorbed on the surface of the catalysts via physical adsorption, followed by ester bond formation via interaction with surface SiOH groups, as evidenced by the formation of characteristic peak at 1737 cm−1. Simultaneously, oleic acid was combined with acidic sites of the catalysts in the form of chelating bidentate adsorption and monodentate adsorption [45,46]. Subsequently, stearic acid was generated via hydrogen saturation of oleic acid, then stearic acid was deoxygenated via the DCN/DCX pathway to form heptadecane by virtue of the strong CC bonds activation ability of Ni species, and amounts of CH4 was detected at 3016 cm−1 by in situ FT-IR spectrometer, indicating that the post-deoxygenation CO and CO2 were further hydrogenated to CH4 [47]. Besides, the CO bond of stearic acid was activated by the hydrogen spillover effect of Ni species on the acidic supports to form octadecane via the RDO pathway, which could be proved by the experiment result. Finally, acid sites facilitated the activation of the CC bonds in heptadecane and octadecane, a series of short-chain alkanes were generated via the HCK reaction. Moreover, the mesopores in KIT-6 promoted the rapid mass transfer for reactants, and the micropores with ten-membered rings in ZSM-22 units offered the possibility of the generation of amounts iso-alkanes [12]. Notably, short-chain alkanes were contacted with B acid sites of the catalyst and underwent an aromatization reaction to form aromatic hydrocarbons. Thus, the presence of high dispersion of Ni species, the hierarchical porous structure and mild acidity of Ni/ZK-2 collectively contributed the remarkable jet fuel yield and iso/n ratio in oleic acid hydrogenation. 4 Conclusions Series of bifunctional hierarchical catalysts with tunable acidity and uniform mesostructure were successfully synthesized. The uniform mesostructure not only facilitated the dispersion of Ni species and adsorption of reactants, but also minimized the diffusion resistance. Besides, the mild acidity optimized the balance between HCK and ISO reactivity and modulated the chemical composition state of Ni via electron transfer with Ni species. The SiOH and acid sites on the supports surface were adsorption and reaction sites for the carboxylic acid groups, which were deoxygenated to generate long chain alkanes and then formed a large number of jet fuel products via HCK and ISO reactions. Ni/ZK-2 exhibited exceptional catalytic proficiency in the production of jet fuel through oleic acid hydrogenation. The mild acidity and open pores optimized MSI and facilitated the dispersion of Ni species, contributing to the enhanced hydrogenation reactivity of oleic acid. This work offered an innovative paradigm for the rational design of high-performance catalysts toward oleic acid hydrogenation by precisely regulating the balance of acid and diffusion property. Besides, the simulation of vegetable oil fractions by adding other model compounds or the direct hydrogenation of vegetable oils to produce jet fuel remained a hot topic in the future research. coredata.dc:description: Bifunctional hierarchical porous Ni/ZSM-22-KIT-6 (Ni/ZK) catalysts with uniform mesostructure and tunable acidity were synthesized and applied to the selective hydrogenation of oleic acid for jet fuel production. The open hierarchical porous channels of Ni/ZK not could facilitate the dispersion of Ni species and reduce the diffusion resistance, but also provide a large number of adsorption sites for reactants. The acidity of the Ni/ZK catalyst was optimized by adjusting the addition of ZSM-22 seeds, and the acidic supports would affect the metal-support interaction and the electronic properties of Ni species. Moreover, the reaction mechanism and pathway were investigated by in situ FT-IR spectrometer, demonstrating that the acid strength could affect the deoxygenation pathway and isomerization/hydrocracking pathway. Overall, Ni/ZK-2 possessed higher jet fuel yield of 60.2 % and iso/n-alkane ratio of 5.6 at 320 °C compared with other heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literatures. For comparison, the iso/n-alkane ratio of commercial Jet A-1 is 1.11, indicating that the jet fuel derived from oleic acid hydrogenation over Ni/ZK-2 possessed enhanced resistance to condensation.
